Transcription-Unit.comment:
The gltBDF operon codes for the glutamate synthase, the large (gltB) and small (gltD) subunits, and a protein that is implied in the self-operon regulation (gltF) [Castano88, Castano92].

The operon is the target of Lrp (global modulator in response to leucine levels, related to nitrogen metabolism) [Wiese97, Oliver87], IHF (global DNA-bending protein), and GadE (regulator for resistance to low pH) [Hommais04] activation, and Nac (regulator for the histidine and nitrogen utilization) [Zimmer00], and Fnr (global regulator in response to respiration changes) [Constantinidou06] repression. The Lrp activation is helped by the IHF binding between the promoter and its proximal Lrp site (the one centered at ?152 bp), by which Lrp gets closer to the σ70 to activate [Paul01].

An important detail about the proximal Lrp and IHF sites is that the same order and approximate distances and sequences of the sites and the promoter are conserved among several related organisms of the Enterobacteriaceae genera [Paul01].

A new site for Lrp controlling positively the gltBp promoter has been identified [Lintner08]. However, it was not considered, since it is 42 bp downstream from the transcriptional start site of gltB [Lintner08].

Under nitrogen-rich growth conditions, the expression of this operon was increased in mutants for two genes that encode two terminal oxidases, cyoA and cydB, and in mutants for two transcriptional regulators, Fnr and Fur [Kumar11].

Evidence-Code.comment: If a mutation in a gene or promoter prevents expression of the downstream genes due to a polar effect, the mutated gene is clearly part of the transcription unit.
The length of the (transcribed) RNA is experimentally determined. The length of the mRNA is compared with that of the DNA sequence and by this means the number of genes transcribed are established.

Evidence-Code.comment: A person inferred, or reviewed a computer inference of, promoter position relative to the -10 and -35 boxes.
The transcription start site is identified by primer extension.

Automated inference. A computer inferred this assertion through one of many possible methods such as sequence similarity, recognized motifs or consensus sequence, etc. When a person made the inference from computational evidence, use EV-COMP-HINF.

Evidence-Code.common-name: A person inferred or reviewed a computer inference of sequence function based on similarity to a consensus sequence.
Evidence-Code.comment: Human inference based on similarity to consensus sequences

Evidence-Code.comment: A cis-mutation in the DNA sequence of the transcription-factor binding site interferes with the operation of the regulatory function. This is considered strong evidence for the existence and functional role of the DNA binding site.

Evidence-Code.comment: A DNA sequence similar to previously known consensus sequences is computationally identified.

Evidence-Code.common-name: ChIP-exo evidence used in manual assertion
Evidence-Code.comment: A type of chromatin immunoprecipation-exonuclease evidence that is used in a manual assertion.

Evidence-Code.common-name: Inferred by a human based on computational evidence
Evidence-Code.comment: Human inference. A curator or author inferred this assertion after review of one or more possible types of computational evidence such as sequence similarity, recognized motifs or consensus sequence, etc. When the inference was made by a computer in an automated fashion, use EV-AINF.

A type of chromatin immunoprecipation evidence that uses high-throughput sequencing where immunoprecipitated DNA fragments are funnelled into a massively parallel sequencer to produce multiple short reads for locating binding sites of DNA-associated proteins. This evidence can be used to probe the binding of proteins, such as transcription factors or RNA polymerase, to DNA.

Publication.title: Escherichia coli Lrp Regulates One-Third of the Genome via Direct, Cooperative, and Indirect Routes.
Publication.author: Kroner GM
Wolfe MB
Freddolino PL

Evidence-Code.common-name: Automated inference based on sequence pattern discovery
Evidence-Code.comment: A sequence found by pattern discovery using computational methods.

Publication.source: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A 105(49);19462-7
Publication.title: Genome-scale reconstruction of the Lrp regulatory network in Escherichia coli.
Publication.author: Cho BK
Barrett CL
Knight EM
Park YS
Palsson BO

Evidence-Code.comment: A fixating agent such as formaldehyde is used to cross-link proteins and DNA. Sonication is applied for DNA shearing. For transcription factor tagging, a specific antibody or an epitope and its antibody are employed. After cross-linking is reversed, the DNA is amplified and labeled with a fluorophore for microarray, which produces a resolution of approximately 500 bp. This evidence can be used to probe the binding of proteins, such as transcription factors or RNA polymerase, to DNA.

Publication.title: Characterization of the regulon controlled by the leucine-responsive regulatory protein in Escherichia coli.

Ninfa AJ
